Graphical abstract A new family of well-defined cobalt complexes (Co1–Co7) bearing N,N-bidentate chelate aldimine imidazolidine-2-imine/guanidine ancillary ligands were designed and successfully synthesized. All of the target metal complexes were structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. It revealed that the Co atom adopted distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry and formed a unique six-membered chelate ring which exhibited structural distinctions with traditional N^N-based α-diimine and β-diimine Co complexes. In combination with a very low amount of Et2AlCl (as low as 50 equiv.), these Co complexes exhibited high activity (up to 99 % yield within 6 hrs) and good thermal stability (up to 80 °C) in the coordination polymerizations of isoprene to afford cis-1,4/3,4-polyisoprenes with adjustable molecular weights M n (25.9–138.4 kg/mol) and cis-1,4 contents (64.7–73.3 %). The different substituents on these Co catalysts also exerted influence on catalytic behaviors, chain microstructures, and polymer properties. This study represents the first example of imidazolidine-imine/guanidine analog ligated Cobalt complexes for the polymerization of isoprene. Keywords Imidazolidine-2-imine Guanidine Cobalt catalyst Coordination polymerization Polyisoprene Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Polyisoprene is a kind of widely used polymeric material with rapid development and huge production in the current rubber industry. The coordination polymerization of isoprene is a powerful catalytic approach that furnishes artificial polyisoprene rubber whose microstructures and properties can largely be controlled through an appropriate choice of catalyst [1,2]. In general, isoprene can be incorporated into the polymer chain through cis-1,4, trans-1,4, 1,2- and 3,4-fashion. Highly cis-1,4-stereoregular polyisoprene exhibits excellent elastic properties and good resistance to abrasion and fatigue, and it has been widely used as the raw material of tires, while the branched polyisoprenes with mixed cis-1,4- and 1,4-units will further decrease its rolling resistance and keep the good wet-skid resistance [3]. A wide variety of metal-based catalysts can promote the specific polymerization of isoprene [4]. Early transition metal catalysts and rare earth metal catalysts can furnish highly stereoregular and regioselective polyisoprene [5–7], and these catalysts have been the dominant players in the polyolefin manufacture. In the late 1990 s, the well-known α-diimine Ni and Pd catalysts [8–10], neutral salicylaldimine Ni catalysts [11,12] and bis(imino)pyridine Fe and Co catalysts [13–15] were successively applied for olefin polymerization. Since then, air- and moisture-stable late transition metal catalysts based on Ni, Pd, Fe, and Co metals have been a research focus in olefin polymerization [16–18], in which the Fe and Co catalysts have been widely used in the polymerization of conjugated dienes due to their significant advantages such as high activity, flexible initiation, strong tolerance toward polar functional groups and low cost. Besides the metal, structures of the chelating ligand also play a significant role in catalytic behaviors. Bidentate and tridentate ligands with N, O, P, and S atoms as the coordination sites have been generally designed to support their Fe and Co complexes in the polymerization of conjugated dienes [19–25]. Among them, the N-containing ligands (imine/amine) stand out due to their simple synthesis, flexibly adjustable substituents, explicit structural property dependency, and the ability to effectively stabilize the central metal. The representative Fe and Co catalysts bearing N,N,N-tridentate pyridine-diimine ligand have been studied extensively [26–28]. Meanwhile, the development of Co and Fe catalysts baring N,N-bidentate chelate bipyridine [29–31], iminopyridine [32–36], iminoquinoline [37], aminopyridine [38–40], α- and β-dimine ligands [41–43] (I–VI, Chart 1 ) have enabled several milestones to be achieved. The development of late-transition metal catalysts bearing novel N-containing ligand platforms will provide potential systems that exhibit enhanced catalytic performance. Zhang et al. recently reported an active pyrazolyimine Co catalyst (VII, Chart 1) for controllable polymerization of isoprene, and the contents of 3,4-unit of polyisoprenes (17.4–67.8 %) are able to be adjusted on a large scale in the presence of external donors [44]. Wang et al. found that the iminoimidazole Fe and Co catalysts (VIII, Chart 1) containing a strong chelating Sp2 N-atom on the imidazole ring exhibited stereoselectivity switchable polymerization of isoprene depending on the type of cocatalyst, and the Co/AlEt2Cl catalysts give polyisoprenes with cis-1,4 enchainments in the range of 68–80 % [45]. Pyridine-oxazoline Co catalysts (IX, Chart 1) developed by Gong et al. polymerized isoprene to give a polymer with typical cis-1,4 unit of 72.1 % and the complex with a –NHP = O side arm is able to promote the efficient copolymerization of isoprene with hydroxylmyrcene to produce polar functionalized copolymers with high hydroxyl contents [46]. Very recently, Wang et al. also reported that the catalytic behaviors of pyridine-oxazoline Fe catalysts (IX, Chart 1) and the polymer microstructures are sensitive to the ligand substituents and the type of central metal [47]. The recently emerging Fe and Co catalysts based on N-heterocyclic structures further enriched the research in the polymerization of dienes, and it also proved the excellence of N-heterocyclic ligands in the olefin polymerization catalysis community. We are interested in a series of highly basic imidazolin-/imidazolidine-2-iminato/-imine ligands and their guanidine analogs for the design of catalyst skeletons. These strong N-donors can effectively stabilize a coordinated metal and their steric hindrance effect can be affected by changing the substituents on the other two N-atoms [48,49]. Excellent catalytic performances have been achieved by using imidazolin-/imidazolidine-2-iminato/-imine ligated early transition metal catalysts (Ti, Zr, and Hf) [50–53] and late transition metal catalysts (Ni and Pd) [54–59] in olefin polymerizations. However, the application of such a ligand platform in the polymerization of conjugated dienes has never been reported. There, with the readily used N,N-bidentate aldimine imidazolidine-2-imine/guanidine ancillary ligands, a series of Co complexes were successfully synthesized. These Co complexes were able to be activated with a very low amount of the aluminum cocatalyst and exhibited good thermal stability, excellent monomer conversion, and high molecular weight of the polymers in isoprene polymerizations. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of the cobalt complexes The N,N-bidentate aldimine imidazolidine-2-imine/guanidine ancillary ligands L1–L7 were easily synthesized through the condensation reaction of different anilines and imidazolidin-2-imine-/guanidine-substituted benzaldehydes according to our recent reported work [55]. The treatment of each ligand with CoCl2 anhydrous in dry dichloromethane under a nitrogen atmosphere led to the formation of the target Cobalt complexes Co1–Co7 in good to excellent yields (73.8–89.6 %) (Scheme 1 ). Single crystals were obtained by slow dilution of n-hexene into a DCM solution of the cobalt complexes at room temperature. All of the obtained cobalt complexes were fully characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, MALDI-TOF MS analysis, and elemental analysis. The molecular structures of complexes Co1–Co7 are shown in Fig. 1 and selected bonds and angles are listed in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 1a and Table 1, all of the complexes Co1–Co7 adopted distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, in which the N1, N2, Cl1, and Cl2 atoms served as four vertices, and the Co atom positioned at the center through Co–N and Co–Cl connectivities. It afforded very close bond lengths of Co–Cl1 and Co–Cl2 and gave Cl1–Co–Cl2 angles within the range of 108.52(5)–116.71(3)°. Each of the Co complexes featured slightly shorter Co–N2 distances than Co–N1 with the differences falling in the range of 0.008–0.043 Å, suggesting the slightly stronger electron-donating property of the imidazolidine-2-imine/guanidine motif compared to the common aniline moiety. A six-membered chelate ring was constituted by the Co atom, the coordinated N1 and N2 atoms, and also the C1, C2, and C3 atoms of the backbone to give an N1–Co–N2 bite angles in the range of 90.90(7)–94.46(6)°. The cobalt center lies out of the coordination plane comprised of N1, N2, C1, C2 and C3 atoms, and the Co displacements were calculated as 0.273 Å (Co1), 0.459 Å (Co2), 0.012 Å (Co3), 0.061 Å (Co4), 0.607 Å (Co5), 0.795 Å (Co6) and 0.169 Å (Co7), respectively. Complexes Co2, Co5 and Co6 exhibited longer Co–N1 distance (2.033(2)–2.053(6) Å) and Co–N2 distance (1.995(2)–2.013(6) Å), as well as larger Co displacements from the coordination plane (0.459–0.795 Å) than those of complexes Co1, Co3, Co4 and Co7, which was probably caused by the increased steric conflict between the N-aryl substituents and guanidine ligand in these complexes (Fig. 1b) [61,62]. The SambVca 2.1 program was applied to visualize and quantify the steric effects caused by different N-aryl substituents around the Co center by the comparison of steric maps (Fig. 1c). Co1 and Co3 bearing an imidazolidine-2-imine ligand have the close Vbur values of 50.9 % and 50.5 %, while the Vbur value of tetramethyl guanidine ligated Co complexes Co2 (51.1 %), Co4 (51.5 %) and Co7 (52.7 %) increased with the increase of the bulkness of 2,6-disubstituted aniline moieties. The terphenyls substituents in complexes Co5 and Co6 were more efficient in blocking the Co center with the Vbur value achieved at 53.7 % and 55.1 %, respectively. Dihedral angles α and β were calculated to give more detailed insights into these new structures, in which the α represents the dihedral angle between the coordination plane (comprising of N1, N2, C1, C2, and C3 atoms) and the N-aryl plane, meanwhile, the β represents the dihedral angle between the coordination plane and the imidazolidine-2-imine/guanidine plane (comprising of N3, N4, and C8 atoms), respectively (Fig. 2 a–2c). The two N-aryl planes are known to be nearly perpendicular to the coordination plane of the typical α-diimine complexes [60]. For the current cobalt complexes, the N-aryl planes were also nearly perpendicular to the coordination plane in all the complexes Co1–Co7 with the dihedral angle α in the range of 84.48–89.99°, except for complex Co2, which has a smaller dihedral angle α of 68.47°. The dihedral angle β of complex Co1 (75.11°) and Co3 (71.60°) was larger than the value of complexes Co2 and Co4–Co7 (59.54–65.16°), indicating the structural difference between cyclic imidazolidine-2-imine ligand and noncyclic tetramethyl guanidine ligand. Compared to the reported Co complexes baring typical α-diimine and β-diimine ligands (Fig. 2e and 2f), the present complexes Co1–Co7 (represented by complex Co1 as shown in Fig. 2d) featured the following differences in the crystallographic structure: (i) The Co–N2 distance in complexes Co1–Co7 were shorter than the Co–N1/N2 distance both in the α-diimine and β-diimine Co complexes, suggesting different electronic property of the N-donors. (ii) Both, the five-membered coordination ring in α-diimine Co complex and the six-membered coordination ring in complexes Co1–Co7 adopted nonplanar configurations with the Co atoms lying out of the coordination plane, affording the N1–Co–N2 bite angles of 80.0(1)° and 90.90(7)–94.46(6)°, respectively, while the six-membered coordination ring in β-diimine Co complex adopted a boat-like configuration with the N1–Co–N2 bite anlge of 94.10(11)°. 2.2 Isoprene polymerization Isoprene polymerization was first studied using Co4 as a representative pre-catalyst to find out the optimal polymerization parameters such as the type of cocatalyst, Al/Co ratio, and polymerization time (Scheme 2 ). The results are summarized in Table 2 . Three kinds of aluminum compounds, EtAlCl2, Et2AlCl, and MAO, were used as cocatalysts for isoprene polymerization with Co4 and only Et2AlCl was confirmed to be an effective cocatalyst since it gave a much higher yield as compared to EtAlCl2 or the MAO systems. The polymerization was then conducted by the Co4/Et2AlCl system under different Al/Co ratios. With the Al/Co ratio increasing from 50 to 100, the polymerization yield increased from 28.6 % to 48.5 % in 6 h, accompanied by slightly decreased M n from 66.5 to 53.6 kg/mol (entries 1 and 2). There is no significant increase in the polymerization yield when the Al/Co ratio was further increased from 100 to 700, however, the molecular weight M n decreased from 53.6 kg/mol to 25.9 kg/mol (entries 2–5), which can be attributed to chain transfer reactions in the presence of excess aluminum compounds. These results suggested that 100 equivalent of Et2AlCl is enough to activate these Co complexes. Therefore, the Al/Co was fixed at 100 in the subsequent polymerization experiments and the influence of polymerization time was also studied. When the polymerization time was extended from 6 h to 24 h, the overall yield disproportionately increased from 48.5 % to 82.5 %, and the molecular weight M n slightly increased from 53.6 kg/mol to 84.1 kg/mol accompanied by broadening PDI (entries 2, 6 and 7), which is caused by the gel effect of the polymerization system by extending the polymerization time. In order to achieve equivalent conversion of monomers, polymerization was conducted with an increased dosage of Co4, and a satisfying yield of 97.6 % was obtained within 6 h while keeping the molecular weight M n almost constant (52.7 kg/mol) (entry 8). The obtained polymers bearing similar microstructure were characterized by 1H and 13C NMR analysis (Fig. S15a and S15b), and they were confirmed to be cis-1,4/3,4-polyisoprenes with cis-1,4-content in the range of 69.0 % to 73.3 %, which is similar to those of the previously reported Co compexes bearing N-heterocyclic ligands in Chart 1 (VIII–IX). With the optimized polymerization parameters, the catalytic behaviors of Co1–Co7 were then tested under varied temperatures from 25 °C to 80 °C, and the results are shown in Table 3 and Fig. 3 . Isoprene polymerization at elevated temperatures are favorable for industrial production since the high temperature can reduce the viscosity of polymer solution, increase the mobility of the polymerization system, maintain well-defined catalytic behaviors of the catalytic system and save energy. The polymerization data shows that the polymerization achieved high monomer conversion at 25 °C and 50 °C with most of the conversions achieved above 99.9 % (Fig. 3a), suggesting the good catalytic capacity of these Co catalysts. At a high temperature of 80 °C, although the monomer conversion decreases as the temperature increases to 80 °C, the Co catalysts are still active with monomer conversions in the range of 31.0–70.5 %. When the temperature increased from 25 to 80 °C, the molecular weight M n decreased in all of the Co catalytic systems accompanied by broadening PDI (Fig. 3c and 3d), which can be attributed to the rapid chain transfer reaction at elevated temperature. The overall molecular weights M n of polymers obtained by these Co catalysts are in the range of 31.6–138.4 kg/mol, and the molecular weight distributions PDI are in the range of 1.7–3.9. There is no crosslinking observed in the polymerization systems and the GPC curves of the polymers all appeared as single modal (Fig. S15c), indicating the polymerization occurred at a single active site. The catalytic behaviors of different catalysts are also investigated. Although there is no significant difference in the yield and molecular weight of the polymers obtained by catalysts Co1–Co4 due to their similar steric effects and close buried volume (%Vbur) value, a further increase in the steric hindrance in the catalysts can effectively enhance their thermal stability. For example, Co5 and Co6 with relatively large steric hindrance have been screened out as the optimal catalysts with good thermal stability since both of the two catalysts can maintain high activity and high molecular weight at high temperatures. When the polymerization temperature is kept identical, the increase in the steric hindrance effect of the catalyst helps to improve the molecular weight of the polymer. For instance, at 50 °C, the highest molecular weight of the polymer was achieved by Co5, which is 2.7 times higher than that of Co2 with a less bulky substituent. The same phenomenon was also observed at 80 °C, the highest molecular weight was obtained by Co7, which is twice as high as that of Co1, indicating that the catalyst with a large steric hindrance effect can prevent the chain transfer reaction during polymerization. However, excessive bulkiness of the catalyst will hinder the coordination and insertion of monomers, this can be confirmed by the results Co7 with multiple t-Bu groups on the common 2,6-substituted aniline always give the lowest yield and molecular weight under a moderate temperature range within 25 to 50 °C. Both, the polymerization temperature and the catalyst structure exert a large influence on the polymer microstructures. The cis-1,4 content in the polymer gradually decreased as the increase of temperature in all of the catalytic systems (Fig. 3b), suggesting that anti-syn isomerization of the Co intermediates through π-σ rearrangement was facilitated at high temperatures [38,39,44]. As the proposed propagation process in Fig. 4 , isoprene monomers first coordinate onto the activated Co center through cis-η 4, η 2, and trans-η 4 pathways, respectively. After 3,4-insertion of isoprene, the obtained anti-η 3 and syn-η 3 allyl-Co intermediates are able to perform isomerization through π-σ rearrangement.[23,39,42,44,63–69] The subsequent coordination and insertion of isoprene at kinetically favored anti-η 3 isomers give cis-1,4 and 3,4 units in the polymer, depending on the insertion of the monomer at the different C1 and C3 atoms.[44,63,70] Similarly, the thermodynamically preferred syn-η 3 isomer will also produce trans-1,4 and 3,4 units in the polymer.[39,42,43,63] The elevated temperature led to the formation of more syn-η 3 isomers so the ratio of 3,4-units increased. Lower cis-1,4 content was generally given by the catalyst with a larger steric hindrance effect. This can be confirmed by the results that Co5 and Co6 with the highest Vbur% value have the lowest cis-1, 4 content (64.9 % and 64.7 %), while Co1 with the lowest Vbur% value gave a higher cis-1,4 content of 69.7 %. These results further suggested that the bulky substituents on the catalyst may reduce the coordination space so that the isoprene monomers are inclined to coordinate in a small-space preferred η 2 pathway instead of the cis-η 4 manner, leading to less cis-1,4 uint in the polymer.[24,42] The T g values of the polymers were then measured by DSC scanned from –90 to 100 °C, and the results are shown in Fig. S15d. As the cis-1,4 content decreased from 73.3 % to 64.7 %, the T g values of the polymer increased from −44.88 to −37.52 °C. 3 Conclusion To conclude, aldimine imidazolidine-2-imine/guanidine cobalt complexes were synthesized and applied for isoprene polymerization. X-ray diffraction analysis results revealed that these new family of Co complexes are distinct from the N,N-bidentate chelate Co complexes that have ever been reported. Upon activation with Et2AlCl, all of the Co complexes are active for isoprene polymerization, which produced cis-1,4- and 3,4-unit mixed polyisoprenes with adjustable molecular weight and cis-1,4-unit content, as well as reasonable T g values. The installation of bulky substituents on the auxiliary ligand helps to enhance the thermal stability of the Co catalyst and also improves the molecular weight of resulted polymers, however, it will take the expense of activity and cis-1,4 content. This study provided the concept for catalyst design and the exploration of the polymerization catalysis of conjugated dienes, and more research on the copolymerization of different monomers is in progress. coredata.dc:description: A new family of well-defined cobalt complexes (Co1–Co7) bearing N,N-bidentate chelate aldimine imidazolidine-2-imine/guanidine ancillary ligands were designed and successfully synthesized. All of the target metal complexes were structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. It revealed that the Co atom adopted distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry and formed a unique six-membered chelate ring which exhibited structural distinctions with traditional N^N-based α-diimine and β-diimine Co complexes. In combination with a very low amount of Et2AlCl (as low as 50 equiv.), these Co complexes exhibited high activity (up to 99 % yield within 6 hrs) and good thermal stability (up to 80 °C) in the coordination polymerizations of isoprene to afford cis-1,4/3,4-polyisoprenes with adjustable molecular weights M n (25.9–138.4 kg/mol) and cis-1,4 contents (64.7–73.3 %). The different substituents on these Co catalysts also exerted influence on catalytic behaviors, chain microstructures, and polymer properties. This study represents the first example of imidazolidine-imine/guanidine analog ligated Cobalt complexes for the polymerization of isoprene.
